message: Can anyone give me an example of either of these -- either hypothetical or from an actual film?
@travelingleonards To Kill a Mockingbird, specifically Scout (equity) and Boo (inequity) as explored via prejudices.
Although that isn't where equity is a problem/inequity a solution.  But it may give you an idea as to how they were used.
Smart kids return, scores increase, and so does the funding. Problem solved.

A school driven to make grading fair for everyone who attends find their smartest kids ditching from boredom and their funding lost from the subsequent low test scores. Making life more difficult and unfair for those kids by connecting grades to attendance (not performance) motivates them to return to school and participate.

A country turns to communism, but the redistribution of wealth decreases living standards, and the politicians are forced to turn to corruption to maintain their power in the unhappy society. Re-introduction of merit-based pay results in better living standards and eventually democracy.

A vicious leader kills everyone in his country who is different, believing that racial and religious homogeneity will result in harmony. His terrorized populace revolts, and returns the country to a harmonious heterogenous mix.

"Everyone gets what they deserve (equity) Death for death", the Demon that becomes more powerful when killing murderers said. In order to end this, the sinless priestess must let him take her life (inequity).
Reading more news today (ugh) sparked another "Equality as a problem" potential: eye for an eye punishment.
Although the article had the unintentionally funny sentence of: "He made threats and harrassed her, even asking her to marry him."
